Wrong. One infinite set can be a superset of another, and yet be of equal size. Example: {1,2,3,...} (set of all natural integers), and {1,3,5,...}, (set of even ones). All numbers from second set are present in the first, but not all numbers from the first set are present in the second. Yet, building a bidirectional mapping between these sets is easy: any "x" from the first set -> "x*2-1" from the second set, any "y" from the second set -> "(x+1)/2" from the first set. So, they are equal size!
Discussing which infinity is larger is like discussing which item is more unique.

This is part of algorithmic theory; all you have to do is show a finite process (i.e., the list of steps) that will do the work.  As long as you can demonstrate that the process would produce the result you want, you don't actually have to run it.  (The difference between an algorithm and a process is that an algorithm is guaranteed to terminate, while the process is not guaranteed to terminate.  It may or may not terminate, but if it does, it will have proved the result.)

1. Take infinity A to be the set of all the rationals between 0 and 1.
2. Take infinity B to be the set of all natural numbers.
3. For every fraction 1/n, for each n in set B, you have a rational. A is > or = B in size.
4. But, for every fraction 1/n, you also have a number x/n, where x and n are coprime, you have another rational number.
5. Size of A is almost size of B *squared*

Actually, there are different degrees of infinity. If you try to make a relationship between positive integers and the reals between 0 and 1, you'll find that there's always a number in the reals that you did not "draw an arrow to" no matter how you define that relationship; as such, there are more real numbers between 0 and 1 than positive integers. They are both infinite, but one IS strictly larger than the other when talking about the cardinality of the set.

one may easily compare the size of two infinities. Given f(x)=x^2/(2-x) and g(x)=x/(2-x) one sees that both f and g approaches infinity as x approaches 2. However if one takes the ratio of f(x) in relation to g(x), the expressions can be reduced to: f(x)/g(x)=x. If you take the limit as x approaches 2, the ratio will be 2. Therefore: the infinity of f(x) as x approaches 2, is twice as big as the infinity of g(x) as x approaches 2. The same idea does also apply in the counting example in video.

It's certainly a counter intuitive concept - strange but true. I like to think about it this way: Take the set whole numbers - this is infinite. Now make a set of numbers that not only includes the whole numbers, but also all numbers with one decimal place: e.g. include numbers like 1.1 and 3.8 etc. For every entry in the first set you have 10 numbers in the second set. Even though they are both infinite, the second set is a larger infinity.

Actually it is true. Please, do some research and come back to me. Integers and Rationals are called 'countable' infinities. You can write them out in an order that includes them all. Yes, In common usage we call all of them "infinity", but like I said, each different infinity has its own special Aleph number. The "smallest" infinity, that of {1, 2, 3...} is Aleph-null, and the "next" infinity (that of the real numbers) is Aleph-one.

They are all still infinite in size, i.e. larger than any real number, but the aleph numbers are different in size from each other.

The word for what he's doing here, linking elements of one set to another, is bijection.

That's the common sense reasoning that the two sizes of infinity are actually the same, but it's wrong.

If you can set up a bijection between two infinite sets then they have the same size. TO do this for the numbers from 0 to 1 and those from 0 to 2 you either double them or half them. Each number in [0,1] has exactly one partner in [0,2] and vice versa, and there are none left over. Hence the sets have the same size.

A = {real numbers 0-1} (eg: 0.23981287409174901837912379812379)
B = {integers 0-infinity} (eg: 2)
n(A) is greater than n(B) because there are an infinite amount of real numbers between 0 and 1, which is (so to say) a greater infinite than 0 to infinity in integers.

It works because there are different sizes of infinity. Just saying that both are infinite does NOT imply that both are the same size.

Here, minutephysics proved that the infinity we use to describe the size of the set of numbers {1, 2, 3...} is strictly smaller than the infinity we use to describe the size of the set of real numbers.

In maths, we can get around the notion of using "infinity" to mean different sizes by using what are known as Aleph numbers (google them if you want).
